Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
• (1) The social service worker shall complete,
sign, and date an initial treatment plan for each
resident within 30 calendar days of admission.
Two of three initial residential service plans in active youth files reviewed were
completed late.

CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
• (1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following information
shall be documented in the case record within
14 days after discharge:
• (a) The date of and reason for discharge,
and the new location of the child.
One of two closed youth files reviewed did not have a discharge summary
documented in the file.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
• (1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following information
shall be documented in the case record within
14 days after discharge:
• (c) An assessment of the resident’s
needs that remain to be met.
One of two closed youth files reviewed did not have an assessment of the youth’s
needs that remain to be met.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
• (1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following information
shall be documented in the case record within
14 days after discharge:
• (b) A brief summary or other
documentation of the services provided
while in residence, including medical and
dental services.
One of two closed youth files reviewed did not have a brief summary of the
services provided to the youth while in care.

CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
• (1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following information
shall be documented in the case record within
14 days after discharge:
• (d) Any services that will be provided by
the facility after discharge.
One of two closed youth files reviewed did not have documentation of what
services will be provided by the facility after discharge.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• It was discussed with the facility that they combine the treatment plans into the
service plan so there is one document holding all of the information necessary
for treatment.
• It was discussed with the facility the need to train the individuals writing the
treatment goals about all of the aspects needed for each goal. A copy of the
service plan’s hidden text was provided to the facility.
• It was discussed with the facility the need to develop a standard form for the
discharge summary. Currently, they are using different forms such as a
MDHHS-69 action summary in some cases.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• No consultation was requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency has submitted the first CAP for their interim inspection in 2023. The
following is a summary of the CAP compliance.

400.4113 (1) (j) written evaluation. During the renewal inspection this issue was
not found to be in violation. The facility has followed the procedure developed to
identify the dates that the different evaluations are due, and the Quality Assurance
department has followed through with oversite.
400.4147 (2) Dental examination. During the renewal inspection this issue was not
found to be in violation. All three open youth files reviewed had the required dental
examination. The medical clerk’s checklist was followed, and oversite provided by
the Quality Assurance department.
400.4155 (1) Initial treatment plan. One of three initial treatment plans was not
completed within the time frame required. This is a repeat violations since during
the renewal inspection it was discovered 2 of 3 initial residential service plans in
active youth files reviewed were completed late. This involved 1 day beyond the
report period ending and 76 days beyond the report period. The facility reported
losing the staff responsible for writing the service plans and there was no process
to ensure the plan was written timely.
400.4156 (1) Updated treatment plan. During the renewal inspection this issue was
not found to be in violation. The facility has followed the procedure developed and
the Quality Assurance department and supervisor were able to provide appropriate
oversite.
400.4166 Discharge plan (1) (a) Date and reason for discharge. One of two closed
youth files reviewed did not have the required discharge plan present in the file.
This is a repeat violations since during the renewal inspection it was discovered 2
of 2 closed youth files reviewed did not have the discharge summaries completed
within 14-days. The process of updating the discharge checklist did not occur in
this case and oversite failed to find this issue.
The second CAP was the response to Special Investigation 2023C0000613 dated
7/25/2023. This CAP involved the administrative assistant documenting the drills
as they take place and the QA individual reviwing this documentation monthly This
was reveiwed by DCWL for 6 months and it was found that the facility was
following through with the action steps of the CAP.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A

Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator documents the change in Chief Administrator at the facility
and identifies the biggest barrier to compliance has been staffing. Replacing
vacant positions has been a significant challenge and impacted the timeliness of
some items (violation of 4155). The facility is in the process of attempting to fill all
vacant positions and this issue is not expected to be long term. The Chief
Administrator addressed the facilities efforts at the CAP activities and notes the
progress and success made to this point. The Chief Administrator also noted their
compliance is not 100% as identified by the violations found during this renewal
inspection. The Quality Assurance aspect of the CAP has been very successful.
Barriers that influenced the unplanned discharges has been addressed and the
number of unplanned discharges has significantly been reduced. During another
special investigation (2024C0000846SI) with no findings but it was recommended
the facility improve their 15-minute overnight bed checks. The facility has
conducted additional training and meetings to process this requirement. In regard
to the violation of 4166 discharge plan, the checklist was found to be ineffective,
and the facility developed and updated the long term foster care file review
checklist which has provided to be very effective.
Staff and Youth Interviews
The first line staff report feeling supported and being supplied with appropriate
training to help provide the environment the youth need for their healing process.
Supervisor staff gave a similar report of being supported by Administration.
Administration reported being open to providing the best practice to youth and
training for all staff.
All of the youth were interviewed. The youth all reported feeling safe at the facility
and having their individual needs met. They reported staff are attentive and
supervise their actions through the day and evening. They believe the program is
helping them reach their goals for movement to another placement.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a single-story facility in excellent condition. It is well maintained, and all
required furnishing were present. The bedrooms were very comfortable and well
ventilated. There are areas for different activities for the youth. The kitchen is well
stocked and very clean. All fire extinguishers were up to date and all plumbing was
in working order. The medication was double locked and appropriately labeled and
stored. Items required to be posted were found posted appropriately.

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
